reviewText: All the fat separators on the market have pretty different mechanisms each purporting to deliver convenience and performance, but this Amco brand version was the easy winner. Because of its cylindrical shape, it's very easy to clean, especially because it is meant to hold hot fat, and anyone who's ever washed the dishes after roasting a fatty hunk of meat knows how difficult things get when a layer of grease is coating the item. I was worried that the handle part would be difficult to clean because that's where the mechanism is, but clean up is a breeze. It's dishwasher safe, too!I didn't like that the OXO brand version required the small plug, which could easily get lost or damaged, so that was eliminated first. The Trudeau brand version has a better sieve lid, but the oval shape seemed conducive to accidental tipping, especially when pouring from a heavy dutch oven.Some tips I've learned along the way are that it's very tough to stop the fat line on a dime, so leaving a half inch of liquid in the separator is preferable to even a little bit of fat getting back into the pot. Also, the longer you leave the fatty liquid in the separator before extracting, the more fat gets trapped. It seems obvious, but when you first pour the fatty liquid in, it's exciting to see the fat line so clearly, so you're tempted to extract right away. Even five minutes makes a big difference!I used to refrigerate the liquid overnight and then discard the fat cap, but cooking a day in advance of intended meal time isn't always practical. Then I went to cutting a small hole in zip top bags, but I didn't feel safe pouring burning hot liquid into that type of plastic. So this is the first fat separator I've ever used, and now I can't imagine cooking without it!
summary: Never used one before, can't live without it now

reviewText: The strainers do their job, but they look a bit flimzy.  I am not sure how long they'l last, but for now they are fine.

I purchased the Hamilton Beach Durathon full size iron (Model No.19800) for $25.00Durathon Full Size Ironand the Black&Decker; (Model No.D2030) for $43.00 at the same time, so i can decide which of them i will keep.I decided to keep the Hamilton Beach Durathon 19800 it's EXTREMELY EASY to iron everything and throws more steam than compared to the more expensive Black&Decker; D2030.Also, i noticed after ironing a shirt, the B&D; D2030 had scratches on its plate already, after one single use/one single shirt.Id like to say, in my opinion: i'm not so crazy about digital irons. I'm a 30 year guy who believes that not everything has to be digital, i believe that irons should not be. I have friends and relatives that have had digital irons and once the screen fades, or stop working, the entire product must be replaced, but that is not the reason i kept the Hamilton Beach over the Black & Decker, i simply kept it because to me its better.The B&D; D2030 its too heavy which i believed its a good thing because its suppose to get rid of wrinckles faster and etc. but it turns out, its not.

I bought this in different times as a gift for my mum, my wife, my brothers' wife and for my neighbour (an old auntie who cooks for us frequently) and it is really amazing with adjustable different particules sizes and led lighting pimps it :) my only complain will come for seating its kinda a small or easy to move. you should try in your kitchen instead of manual grinders

I first purchased the Breadman Ultimate because of the 3 pan sizes but also purchased a used West Bend without the double pans. For several weeks. I ran tests on both bread machines and pans. I like to pit the same recipe from different authors to see which recipe I prefer by using the dual pans. It has saved frustration and cut down on my cookbooks at the same time--more storage!Amazon was out of stock with this pan but shipped it earlier than stated. I'm glad I purchased it because the Breadman had to be returned since it was defective. Amazon was very cooperative and I learned a lot about the newer machines.These pans will do more than make bread! Because of the readout controls on the West Bend, I can bake a loaf of bread and an oven casserole at the same time (readout gives the oven temp AND length of bake time.  That way the meal is all in one.I use the dough cycle for the bread and when ready to bake, add my casserole to the second pan.I use the dough cycle to mix the bread with the second pan empty without a paddle. When the dough has risen, I add the casserole or dish I want to bake. I then program it for bake or resume the cycle I used to mix the bread (different temperatures).  The machine alerts me when everything is done! No overcooking this way...I also bake desserts in smaller portions with this pan. Nice to bake something for breakfast and snack at the same time (and mix too!)At first I was concerned because of the reviews for the West Bend manual but downloaded the new copy which is much better.I also wondered how hard it would be to get 2 small loaves from the pans....easy if you turn them upside down and let them cool.I am enjoying this bread machine!

I have bought about a dozen vacuums in 40 years, some expensive and some not so much. Although, I liked many of them when first purchased and was lucky that most lasted a long time, this is the nicest one I've ever had. I probably would not have paid 300 or more but at less than 200, I feel it's a steal of a deal. It is light and very easy to manuever with the smaller head. It feels self propelled on my low pile carpets and works great on low power for area rugs also. I never have to stoop for any reason and travel from room to room with ease. Hardwood, tile, and low pile large area rugs are all easy. I would not have purchased this for other types of carpet or rugs as I wouldn't trust the self adjusting roller for deep plush or loopy carpets. After using a bagless type for the last 10 years, I'm really glad I went back to bagged. Myself and the nearby areas were always a dusty mess after emptying the dust container. The dust would make me sneeze. I like this vac so much that if anything happens to it, I'm gonna cry. I have found the small cannister to be a real help with vacumming high to low and much less cumbersome to reach high areas than my rolling cannisters or my uprights. I do wish it had a blower feature like some carry cannisters to blow out under my fridge and stove but oh well. I hope this lasts a long time.
summary: Best Vac ever purchased in 40 years

reviewText: I like this pillow.  The bird design is cute.  The fabric is nice and it seems to be put together well.

This is a very pretty device, but it has fewer grating choices than lower-priced graters.  The two larger sides are for grating course or grating medium.  The two shorter sides are hollow.  On other graters, the shorter sides offer two additional grating options.  It bothers me when a basic kitchen utensil is "improved" to the point of reducing its functions.  What's most missed is an option for fine grating.The grater is well made and attractive.  Usually, metal graters are just that, and they don't win prizes for their looks.  The splash of color in hard plastic is striking, but it doesn't make up for functionality.  This device might find itself in the Museum of Modern Art as an example of sleek and forword-thinking design, but as a completely useful kitchen tool, it falls short of expectations.
summary: Pretty, but short on grating options

reviewText: After reviewing the many products and their respective reviews available on the Amazon website, I selected this Coleman Cable Power Stake with light sensor.  The intended function is to turn on our Christmas lights at dusk, and shut them off at bedtime.  This product is best suited for outdoor use, and the "turn-on" function triggered by dusk.  The "turn-off" function can be triggered by daylight or by a manually-set timing dial.The product is well-made and of rugged materials, durable, easy to use and is perfect for the intended purpose.  The timer switch does not allow total flexibility as do other timers reviewed and available, but is perfect for this intended function.  The six available sockets, three on each side, allow all our lights to plug in and function well.The stake provided is perfect for use in a front lawn, and anchors the product well.  I highly recommend this Coleman product for this type of use.Robert

It is so hard to find comforters for kids that are bright and colorful and COTTON. This is not 100% cotton, but better than the 100% polyester everywhere else. The colors are very vibrant and my 2-year-old LOVES to point out all of the different types of vehicles. The sheets and pillow case are square and fairly soft for a low-thread-count sheet. You'd think manufacturer's would sell high thread count sheets for kids since they have to be washed so often!

reviewText: Fiskars 7861 Axe and Knife Sharpener is very good !! Fiskars is an excellent company that has made quality products for quite some time ! You want REALLY SHARP Knifes / axes ??? Get THIS and you'll be glad you did...We are !!! (-:)

This is not my first pressure cooker. I was looking for a replacement for some weirdo one my hubby's ex left him years ago. I have a giant-sized Presto pressure canner and love it. So I like Presto and liked the size of the ex's weirdo canner. (weird because it had handles that came off all the time, no instructions, no visible brand I could find and was a strange operator.)I wanted stainless steel--easier in the long run, to clean and to cook in. Six quarts is just about the perfect size since I rarely cook for a crowd anymore.This is a nice, solid, reliable cooker. Presto does a good job on the owners manual, some basic recipes, etc. The cooker has a little rack so you can keep your meat off the floor of the cooker.This is not a canner. You could (and I have) use it as a little baby canner for a small load of small jars. I have used it as a canner for about 4-5 pints. The instructions do not say this is a canner, and you probably should know what you're doing if you plan to can with this. It takes about the same amount of time whether you can in this or in the giant cooker, so why not do a large load, I say.Pressure cooking doesn't necessarily save time depending on what you're cooking, when you consider it takes a while to build the pressure. This takes some practice, and knowing your food and your stove. I like it because it cooks meat really tender quicker than any other method.It takes very little experience to get to know the proper pressure without a guage. It makes a rythmic rocking noise, not too fast,not too slow.I find clean up a breeze. This baby is dishwasher safe. I soak it a couple minutes, if needed, then pop her in the DW. Take the rubber gasket off first. You should always hand wash the gasket.

So far, I am pleased with this purchase. It quickly heated up, and it does as well of a job on my kitchen floor as the traditional sponge mop did – and with much less water to clean up afterwards. No, miracles don't happen, so it doesn't clean the grout.  However, it did do a really good job of cleaning out the hairspray on my bathroom floor that lingers after daily styling. I'm glad I purchased this and I mentioned using it more often than I wanted to use the sponge mop.
summary: Does not clean grout but cleans kitchen tile with less mess than a sponge mop and cleans hair spray from bathroom floor

reviewText: I payed approx. $100 when this product first came out a few years ago, and I still think the purchase cost of product was worth every penny.I love this multi-function blender/processor.I use it on a regular to freshly grind coffee!I need additional short cups since I usually store additional grounded coffee in it for 1-3 more uses for a week or two, and possibly 2 more closed lids cuz I take my fresh orange carrot juice (I buy prewashed baby carrots and mix it in with OJ) "to go" in the morning sometimes...which takes 2 seconds to make thanks to the magic bullet blender!Plus since it lready sits so conveniently on the counter I often make crushed beans with it for quesadillas, nacho chip dip, and veggie enchiladas (I just nuke it in the microwave for 3 minutes-dinner plate reheat-button) after using it for beans I store the left over bean paste (mixed with canned crushed or stewed tomato sauce and jalapeno) into the fridge for next time I want a 5 to 15 mintute prep meal! Then I have to use it to make salted (frozen or shaken) margaritas to go with my mex meal too!bar margarita = TSLTT= tequila (1 shot = 2 second count with pourer)S= sour mixL= Lime juice (not the green one, but the yellow sweetened kind) (1 shot = 2 second count with pourer)T= Triple Sec (a.k.a. Orange Liquer) (1 shot = 2 second count with pourer)fill glass with ice, add the measured ingredients, finish filling with sour mix.empty into mixer, moisten rim of just emptied glass with lemon or lime wedge, invert into salt(optional jose cuervo margarita specialty salt).mix the liquids, and pour back into salted glass.
summary: worth every penny even when I payed approx. $100 when it first came out.

A few years ago, I tried heating with space heaters instead of the central gas heat.  This saved a lot of money, so I went to all space heaters and have bought many types.  One thing I've found is that no matter what type of radiant heater I've purchased, it doesn't heat the room as quickly or as well as even a small inexpensive fan unit.  Thankfully, this unit has fans, and the noise level is the typical low hum.  Also, I've started using programmable thermostat timers to give the functionality of a central heating thermostat.  To have these work, the unit needs to turn back on after a power disconnect.  This Ambia heater does that too.  However, these two things are also true of some less expensive heaters.The unique aspect of this heater is the ability to heat in two (up to 6' apart) locations, which is very handy for more evenly distributing the heat in a room.  Drafty rooms are managed better, with less of a "heat pocket" only around the heater.  It is also good for directing at one person from multiple locations to avoid one side feeling cold, or allowing two people to have their own.  In the latter case, those two people need to be close together.  It may be more practical to buy two space heaters and set each to low power. Speaking of settings, this unit allows either side to be on individually, or both to be on simultaneously.  There is no low power setting which allows both sides to output heat.  I think this is a fine compromise to avoid too many controls.  Although it looks like both sides detach, only one does.  That side can also be kept on the base at a different angle, which is nice, but the way it attaches is a bit flimsy and unintuitive.  The aesthetic of the unit could use some work, and the bland grey color doesn't help, but the look is not offensive.Overall, this is a good heater with a clever twist.  In terms of heat output, it does well, as any ceramic heater with this power usage should.  If the price is right, I would recommend it.
Very heavy, well made, does what it should. Holds multiple heavy coats and towels without a squeak of protest. Worth the money.

This is the most beautiful and the most gigantic cutting board you will ever see.  I bought it to use as extra counter space in my kitchen.  It is exactly what I needed.  The board is so beautiful you won't want to use it though.  Made in the USA!

This is a very nice scale for low-weight weighing. The load limit is just over four pounds, so be careful when weighing larger items. My wife uses anEatSmart Precision Pro Digital Kitchen Scale, Silverto weigh wax and scents for her candle company, but she is moving to this scale. She says that the glass top is far better than the top on her other scale, as this top can be easily removed for cleaning. This has been great for her, as the wax gets all over things at times and removing the top and cleaning is great.Another great function of this scale is the ability to convert from pounds and ounces into kilos and grams. This makes it a lot easier to figure things that need metric readings. The readings on this scale are dead on with her other scale, so either they are both very accurate or they are both wrong exactly the same :D... I think that they are probably both very accurate.The only issue is with the amount of weight it can hold, but this won't matter for the average consumer, as they won't be weighing things that are over four pounds that often.
Makes Life So Much Easier When You Have Places For Everything.IThe Holder Can Fit Your Needs A Well. Its Awesome.

I thought it was going to be a major pain when they banned plastic bags and started charging for paper ones in unincorporated LA.  But this 10 pack of bags made the only issue remembering to get them out of the car when going into the store.  And with 10 of them, there's enough to leave half of them in each car. The mattress is very comfortable and my son is very happy with it.

I thought I was ordering regular oven mitts, you know the regular size. Imagine my surprise when I opened the package to find two tiny little mitts. But guess what? These are INGENIOUS! Just the right size and you can slip them right onto the pot or pan handle and leave it there. I am so glad that I messed up and ordered these.
summary: small and just the right fit

reviewText: I use my jars as decorative pieces around my house - in the kitchen I have different sizes displayed in a row on my counter, in my bathroom I put colored pebbles in the bottom of one and store my makeup brushes in it, and in my garage I use them to hold screws on my workbench.  In a pinch I guess I could also use them to store food in - but they're almost too pretty not to be displayed!
summary: Awesome jars - a very pretty blue!

reviewText: I didn't realize how much I hate the banding.  The product was pictured correctly, but I was trying to add to my dozen towels (with no banding).  I don't like the banding at all, and don't use these towels that I just bought.  I can't find any towels of the right size without banding.

It's not airtight!  I bought two (17&23 cup), and maybe I just got two bad ones but neither one is what I would call airtight.  If I put a cup of water in them, snap on the lid and turn them upside down they have a steady leak.  Any pressure on the side walls will cause an audible leak of air, and then the air gets sucked back in by the walls returning from dented state.For something that says "Airtight" on the label, they are very disappointing.  Snaps seem very flimsy as well.  It will probably keep moths out, which is what I wanted, but boy am I disappointed that no reviewer pointed out the complete lack of airtightness.  23 cup size will easily fit a 5lb sack of flour, with a scoop and room.
summary: Not AIRTIGHT.  Flimsy snaps don't always stay locked.  Very disappointing.

reviewText: It works well,must have for anyone thinking seriously about healthy diet.I got the chrome one and it matches perfectly my stainless steel appliances ! Highly recommended!

I purchased 6 of these crates for a utility room counter (see the image posted above).  My space was limited, and I wanted something that would be sturdy (as compared to some wooden peg models I have seen), easy to clean (you can take these outside and hose them off, or put in the dishwasher on the rinse cycle), and store the most bottles.  After measuring the space, and looking at all the other options I could find online, these were the best for me.  Being able to place bottles on top was also perfect for my situation.One question I initially had was whether they would stack vertically--the answer is no--there is no groove to hold the crate in place like when it is placed horizontally.I thought the price was a bit high until I got them--they are very well made--thicker/heavier than expected--and should last forever.

Easy to use, manual easy to understand and assemble and cooks super fast.I followed the guidelines for cooking dry beans and noticed that they can use a couple more minutes more of cooking than the cooking book suggests, just make sure you have plenty of stock or water or it will burn the bottom. The only down part is that you can;t see through the lid to notice if you are running low of liquid :(

We've had this on our bed for over a year now, and it is still in great shape.  It repels coffee spills, but is also comfortable to sleep on.  It does not have that hot, plastic feel that some cheaper models have.  It is a great buy!
The delivery was prompt. My wife is happy with the skillet. It preforms as advertised and its a good pan to add to her already huge collection of cook ware.

I am so glad I read the reviews of all the colanders and bought this one!  I have had it 2 days and I have drained pasta, washed rice, and rinsed salad greens in it. The grippy handles stay put when it's in use.

What an excellent knife!  The blade is very sharp as delivered and thick enough for good feel and should stand up to future sharpenings.  Not as thick as a $200 knife.  As I understand it, this is a stamped blade - not forged.  But it feels and acts like a good knife.While preparing only my second meal with this knife, before I knew it I had sliced through about half my finger nail and a quarter of my finger.  Fortunately, not such a deep cut that I discovered the bone cutting ability of the Victorinox, but enough to attest to its facility with meat.  I'm sure a top end Wusthoff would've taken off the whole finger, but I am more than satisfied with the performance of this blade.  Especially at this price!

I got the standard medium-density pillow and am very happy with it. I sleep on my stomach, and It has just the right amount of give and seems very well made. This is the first pillow I've bought in a long time I'm happy with. I just hope it holds up and lasts. Whether it holds up and lasts is the real test. So many times a pillow, especially a cheap one, will rather quickly turn into a lumpy mess. Time will tell with this one.

I have both an indoor and outdoor drying system. When I opt out of using my electric clothes dryer (as often as possible), I use these soft grip clothes pins with my delicates on my gull-wing dryer. They are very nice to clothes. They do not seem like they'd hold up to a good, stiff wind outdoors, though. I LOVE THEM and am so happy that I bought them for inside drying! None have come apart in the two months I've used them, although I do not over-tax them (two socks per clothes pin). And, they are pretty to boot!
summary: Can't Be Beat for Indoors Drying

reviewText: Good buy.  Buying in bulk is the way to go.  Purchase a years worth so as not to run out and change filters frequently.

I, too, have used one of those cheap plastic mandolines (along with Cuisinart and a good chef's knife) for years.  Although I really like using my cheapy model, it's rather light and not so steady.  This looked like a good design.  The various reviews made it sound quite sharp (as it should be.)When received, the design is fine, the weight is good. The adjustment isnt that hard to figure out (if you've used a mandoline before, or other carpentry equipment. If not, you might be totally confused.)  Mushrooms and other vegetables are reasonably sliced.  But, even for these, I was rather taken aback at the difficulty at the end of the slice. (Rather, it would TEAR, not cut.)  Trying this on anything less firm was an absolute DISASTER.Clearly, not worth the money.  Get the El Cheapo, or get a Real Mandoline.
This grill cover is attractive and works very well. Looks just like the picture. Very well made. I would recommend it.

reviewerName: Beth DeRoos "Beth DeRoos from the California ...
reviewText: We bought this brand toaster in the two slice chrome finish and WOW what a great machine!  It is not a light machine but has some weight to it which we like, as well as a non slide bottomThe three button (bagel, defrost, release) are on the one end of the machine and are easy to use and read as well as classy looking. And the toast turns out absolutely perfect!It is a machine we are proud to have in our kitchen.  It is the second machine this company makes (bought their coffee-espresso-cappuccion machine as a gift for my husband) that I have bought and I recommend the maker to anyone who wants a quality product at an excellent price.
summary: The best toaster and classy as well

reviewText: The manufacturer of such items as this handsome Savannah collection know their  customers. Women (and men, too), are going to go for something attractive in cookware no matter what it is and this red and cream set is going to please any home chef, right from the start - better a Cadillac than a jalopy. The set is aluminum and therefore light weight. We were tickled by the rivets that attach the stainless steel handles to the pots and the see-through tops – the big rivets are a designer item and they are classy. The ensemble includes three covered saucepans of various sizes, a six quart covered stockpot, two skillets, a slotted spatula and a slotted spoon.We have not had the set long enough for comments about its durability. The interior non-stick surfaces in the unusual ivory color we feel should be protected from the start, so we use Pam cooking oil, olive flavor on the skillets. The plastic spatula, of course, protects the surface as well as the oil, and engineer the removal of fried eggs from the pan a success. Our chili turned out fine in the stockpot and of course the glass lids enable quick peeks. The stockpot can go in the oven at 350 degrees but we just let our chili simmer on the stove for a couple of hours.Yesterday I saw a similar pot and pan collection in Walmart's. The pots were of a similar color as our Savannah, but the price was about $30.00 more, so we feel we have a bargain here with our handsome Savannah collection.
summary: Our kitchen is much spruced up by this colorful ensemble!

reviewText: These knives are great! They were incredibly sharp coming our of the package and have maintained that sharpness through much use and abuse over the past month. The handles are comfortable to grip, even for me with small hands. The only downfall is that the block doesn't have room for more knives, so if these are not the only knives you have, you either will have two knife blocks or a drawer of knives.

The unit produces a fine cup of coffee and takes up less space than the model that it replaced.  While at least two of the orignal mounting holes were touted to fit the new model, I did have to drill four new holes.  The only problem that we encountered with this item was with the hot water strainer.  It dropped a few times and had to be snapped back in place.  Other than that, we're delighted with the coffeemaker.

I was really happy when I first bought this unit.  It seemed like it would be everything you would want in a coffee machine, all in one unit.So I set it up and brewed my first pot of coffe.  Everything worked fine until I tasted the coffee.  Not quite hot enough.So I checked the manual.  As other reviewers mentioned, the manual says the coffee is brewed at 200 degrees and maintained at 180 degrees.  Not!!!!  My coffee was brewed at 170 and maintained around 160.  Definitely not hot enough.So I emailed Capresso.  They wrote back that I should definitely send it in for service.So I did.And they sent it back to me, unrepaired.It still brewed coffee at 170 and maintained around 160.So I tried calling them.And I tried on and off for about 4 hours to call them.And their phone system would answer, and tell me to hold.  Then after five minutes on hold, it would say everyone was too busy.  It would tell me to call back later and then hang up on me.So I took the unit back to the store and bought another brand.Because of the lukewarm coffee and poor service, I cannot recommend this product.
Great cover, fast shipping, and best price.  Using it for my new Genesis E320 and it fits like a glove.
Nice big thick towels...wash in cold water for the first few times, they do bleed. I will buy more of these!!!!

I purchase another blanket from Amazon based on the reviews and found it to be very thin even though it was soft. Really appreciate the fact that this one is larger and more plush. Gave the other one to my four-year-old granddaughter and she really likes it. Would absolutely get another Serasoft blanket.

I bought this mug back in January, before the listing noted that it has a non-stick lining.  At that time, it was listed as stainless steel.I got it for a friend who loved it, except the lining.  He got a different mug, gave me this one back and I proceeded to use it as my coffee mug.  That was April.Then, in about September, I noticed that it made my coffee creamer taste "fatty".  I figured it needed a good cleaning.  I also noticed that it didn't seem to be coming as clean as it was before.  Not even the sanitize cycle on my dishwasher will clean the coating.  I finally contacted Zojirushi to inquire about the problems I was having with my dairy creamer spoiling in the mug.This is the answer I received this morning:"Dear xxxx,Thank you for your inquiry.Please do not use dairy products or it may spoil and clog the stopper. Please see the instruction manual for the detailed information.[...]Sincerely,Chico "In summary, DO NOT USE DAIRY PRODUCTS IN THIS MUG OR IT "MAY" (WILL) SPOIL.Update:  After contacting Zojirushi directly to inquire about a replacement mug, because the description mentioned nothing about a lining (at that time, 01/13), this is the reply I recieved:"We are not responsible for what Amazon.com says to sell our products. Please contact Amazon.com to further assist you."

I have a 36" range and the stone that is sold by the manufacturer is several hundred dollars - not something that I'm interested in purchasing if I don't have to.  But, I do want to take advantage of the extra room inside.  I bought two sets with the hope that I could create a custom fit on one of the racks in my range, which I was able to do with one cut on one stone.  The stone cut very easily with a standard wet tile saw and left a nice, clean edge.Performance of the stones will be evaluated this afternoon as I make my first bread on them - I'm not concerned, though.  I will update the review if I have any problems.  The surface is nice and clean, and I've done a test heating run on them with no complaints.Some have argued that you can buy similar tiles from a home improvement store, but I would be cautious about buying stones with unknown content.  Buying these, I'm comfortable knowing that they don't contain toxic chemicals or heavy metals in the clay, and that they have been designed for repeated heating and cooling.  The manufacturer, Joe, is also very responsive to individual requests for information, even on a weekend.
summary: Easy to cut stones to fit a larger oven

reviewText: I wasn't sure just how much use I'd have for this until I was trying to remove a blistering hot bowl of soup from my microwave - not an easy task when using mitts or a towel.  Then I thought of the gripper - Wow!  the only easy way to get that hot bowl out without spilling it or burning myself.It's also the best tool everz for removing cookie sheets and sheet pans from the oven.Now I'm sold and I keep it near the micro in a tool caddy.
summary: I wasn't sure how useful this was going to be

reviewText: I was surprised by the quality of the set. The pans and pots are great!I love the tools that come with the set.This is perfect for me as a single, I dont use my kitchen alot though.

I have had this toaster oven for almost 4 years. It still works OK. There are some drawbacks. It was hard to mount under the cabinet so I never did end up mounting it. It just sat on the countertop. It is difficult to clean/keep clean. The toast function is ok but uneven for the most part. Baking works well. But the timer will only work for 30 minutes and then it turns off. I don't like that because there are many times in which you would like to bake something for more than 30 minutes.

The cord is short and the plug keeps coming out of the wall.  I'll update when I change the bag.  Does vaccum o.k. and I rotate it every 3 times with Dyson Animal  I like the lightweight of it for hurry up jobs.

This iron works like a champ.  Based on the awesome reviews like from LBP, this iron is all that.  The steam factor is amazing,going from a hotter setting to a lower setting is a breeze and only seconds away, steam setting is adjustable and bottom line this is a great product!  I did however take it one step further and buy it at Bed, Bath & Beyond where I was able to use my 20% off coupon which by they can can be used even if they expire! What a bargain!!

These are great, as they are actually biodegradable and make transfer easy.  I was originally using nothing to line my compost pail, and eventually things started building up and getting nasty.  This avoids the mess and makes life easier.
It arrived out of its box but not harmed.  It is as described.  I do wish it had a retractable cord.

These look like the picture, but be advised they come wrapped together in cellophane (no box).  I was really disappointed with that as it will be hard to give them as a gift.  Clearly a bulk item that someone is just throwing together at the warehouse.  It should say that in the ad.
summary: Not packaged to be a gift...

reviewText: Cant wait tio bring these to a concert!  sturdy and look great! overall great quality A in my book! Summer cant soon enough!

It's a very nice, high quality feeling duvet. It's very light feeling. I love that  it's oversize so it covers all sides of my bed. The fill doesn't bunch up.I just wish "Light (referring to warmth/fill) Kingsize" wasn't so warm.  If anyone can recommend a duvet like this but really cool/not as warm as this one, PLEASE let me know.  Thanks in advance.I haven't had any problems with feathers leaking out and I've had mine for over a year.
summary: It's light, love it's oversize; wish "Light" wasn't so warm

reviewText: I had little faith in this item when it first arrived, but it actually works quite well! Is it as good as an omelet made on the stove-top? No. But it's certainly good for those mornings when you're in a hurry, or those late nights when you're hungry and lazy.I've made a few different omelets with this...a plain cheese omelet, a cream cheese one, and a sausage and cream cheese omelet. They last two (once I got the hang of it) turned out great. It may take you one or two times to figure out how much time works best with your microwave, but I haven't had any major issues. I have noticed that if you use only two eggs vs three, the middle doesn't cook as evenly, so I just started using three eggs for each one. Oh, and this is 100% truly non-stick. I usually spray even non-stick items with Pam first, but there was no need with this, the omelet slides right out onto a plate.Overall, I'm pretty happy with this! I still prefer my omelets made in a pan, but this is just fine for when I want something quick and easy.
I was surprised at how soft this rug was for the shower.  Perfect rug and would certainly recommend it to others!

It came. I was excited. Then I opened the box. Eh. It is kind of flimsy in construction. But I started out cheap thinking I could upgrade later. If you're serious about glass cutting and glass art, but something more sturdy. If you simply want to practice your hand at making circle cuts on small bottles for cheap, start here. The kit does include the gritty sand stuff!!!

I wrote a 5 star rating just after I received these 1000 tc sheets.  They were soft and very comfortable.  But now, 3 1/2 months later, I awoke with n 8" tear in the fitted sheet.  That was a big disappointment.  I expected better.

Bought this for my daughter-in-law, as she wanted a small server for bars.  I read reviews on the Pampered Chef server, and it appeared the plastic handle on the newer version tended to have issues.  This one I bought had great reviews, and my dil was pleasantly surprised when she saw that it matched her stainless!!  Who'd have thought?

I throw my basil leaves in before I make pesto...it fully dries just about any veggie you can think of, and de-seeds sliced tomatoes fast and cleanly.The insert makes a great colander, so I wash my smoothie fruits in it, then spin. Great gadget..and it collapses to a very thin 3".
Item arrived damaged due to slim packaging.  Fan required to run 24-7 and unit seemed loud.  Control panel sticker was coming up.  I would not recommend this product.

This is fairly easy to assemble although a little hard to line up all shelf pieces evenly and get them stuck down.  It assembles with pre-stuck 3M tape which has non-recyclable plastic strips so not so eco-friendly.  The backing looks tacky, just heavy cardboard.  Would have liked to leave it off but directions say it must go on for stablity. Also some of the edges were slightly damaged in spite of some heavy duty cardboard packaging. Would not buy another one.
summary: Okay product...more college dorm than home quality.

reviewText: Note - This spatula is angled for right-handed users. The page doesn't say this (that I saw), but note the angle. If you are a lefty this probably isn't the right choice! You can still use it of course, but you won't be getting the right angle on the leading edge.For some reason this is highly recommended. It's a flimsy piece of plastic. Yes, it's heat-resistant and it's very simply so it will never rust or break, but it's such a basic product that I'm surprised it's not half the price. For this price I expected it to be more supple and to better track the contours of the pan. Rather it's rigid and a bit awkward.
summary: Eh, it's ok if you are right-handed

reviewText: I purchased this mattress mostly based on prior experience. I had purchased a memory foam mattress from Amazon about 4 years ago and it was perfect - and comfortable. I thought I was buying the same item based on price and description. I bought this mattress about 6 months ago when I moved. It's not the same mattress! As others noted it never expanded to the full 10 inches (mine went to about 9 - which is OK) but the lower corners (especially 2) of the lower-firm-foam didn't fill out much - the corners are only about 4 or 5 inches thick. This does not affect sleeping comfort and actually makes it easier to put the fitted sheets on. At $300 vs. $1200+ for local priced twin memory foam I suppose one can't complaint too much - but I would not have accepted such a defect if I didn't have to send it back - and that's not easy from Alaska. After sleeping on the mattress for 6 months it is very comfortable and still no "dips" in my usual sleeping position - but those corners still bother me every time I change the sheets! Considering the price I would still buy my next memory foam mattress from Amazon but would not buy this brand.
summary: Sarah Peyton twin memory foarm mattress

reviewText: I purchased this unit at BBY two years ago. I thought it did a good job. I had a little problem with white dust at first. However, I bought the demineralizer capsules made for the unit and that seemed to help. (Using distilled water would work even better.) I used the humidifies about 3 months a year during the heating season. This year when I got it out, it made hideous noises. I had noticed before that if the machine is even slightly off-balance, it will make a similar noise. But nothing I tried to do to balance the machine seemed to work. I think the motor is just dying.PROS:1) Clean and quiet (unless it's off-balance)2) No messy cartridges to deal with3) No mold issues, like warm-mist cartridges seem to have. (However, you must completely empty and clean the machine every 1-2 weeks.)CONS:1) Can be pricy unless you get it on sale2) Will need to fill it daily, if you keep it at a medium setting3) Not built to last more than 2 heating seasons, so don't overpay for it
summary: good, but not built to last

reviewText: This sugar bowl is of good quality, but  I didn't realize how small it was.  It holds a half cup of sugar at most.  It seems well designed except for the nub of a handle.  It should be longer or else have a better shape for ease of grasping.  It seems like manufacterers often put very little thought into design practicality.  All someone would have to do is make a proto-type and try it out with ease of use in mind.  Then something like this would be obvious.  It is very cute, however.
summary: good , but with one design flaw

reviewText: Just a warning that I have received this holder twice without its lid. Seeing some earlier posts that say the lid just lays on the top of the container may be partially to blame for how this could come from a warehouse without its lid. And now I noticed a post a year ago that said this happened to them. Customer service has been fantastic but now I'm returning two toilet holders with no lid and have to start over. One thing that is wonderful about Amazon though is the fact that when things like this happen, there is recourse. When I reported the first one missing its lid, they overnighted a second one immediately. When that one didn't arrive with the lid, they emailed me paid return slips to get it back to them and said they were addressing the problem at the source. It probably ended up working out in my favor anyway... I would not be happy to find that the top has a clear lid and I would not have liked a lid that just sat on top without at least capping over the sides.
summary: Customer service exceptional, but received twice without lid

reviewText: I thought these were the best thing since sliced bread until Rabbi told me the ice cubes tasted terrible.I found this strange as I use bottled water to make ice cubes in a plastic tray with a top.I let some ice cubes melt that had been made from a bottle of water topped off with the Magic Tap and the water tasted bad.I drank some water from that bottle and it tasted bad.I opened a new bottle of water bought at the same time and it was fine.Something is causing the Magic Tap to alter the taste of the water.It works just fine but somehow attracts some breakdown of the taste.
summary: Can spoil the taste of the water

reviewText: This is a double-swivel aerator, so it reaches more of the sink than the typical swivel aerator most people use.  You pay a bit more for this than its more generic counterpart, but it's definitely better-constructed, not as likely to crack when tightened, seems to be all metal with black plastic (rather than silver plastic w/black plastic, as many are).  It's a compression aerator but doesn't make the high squealing noise, which my daughter finds very annoying, that similar cheaper ones do.Short of an actual separate hose sprayer, this is the best sink option I've seen.On the other hand, our fridge is black but I don't know if the lack of a white version would annoy those who are fully-color-coordinated.============It's almost 3 years later, and I've moved twice since writing the above review.  My current residence again does not offer a separate sink sprayer in the kitchen, so I went looking for another double-swivel aerator, and ordered this one for its primarily-metal construction, price, and design.  When I went to review the product, I found my own review from 2009, which I'd completely forgotten about;  I hadn't actually set out to buy the exact same product, and I didn't remember which I had bought before.Now, in 2012, I had already tried buying two different double-swivel aerators from local stores, and been disappointed in both.  Both seem to decrease my already borderline water pressure in this 100-year-old house, and neither could reach the far corners of the fairly large porcelain double sink.This aerator again reaches areas that others can't reach, through the combination of its length and double-swivel design.  The packaging notes that it has an "improved design", and I will say that it shifts from normal to spray with very little effort (something that is never true of the plastic aerators.)  And it does quite significantly increase the strength of the water flow coming from the faucet, rather than cutting the flow as most of the other aerators do.As other reviewers have noted, what are pluses for me may be detractions in different circumstances.  If you have a shallow sink and/or a faucet whose end is too close to the sink itself, the length of this aerator  will make it difficult to fit a pot or other large object underneath without working around the protrusion.  And if your water pressure is already great, you may find that the increased pressure causes water to splash all over when you just turn on the faucet normally.  (It even splashes a bit here at times, when I forget that I don't have to turn on the faucet full-force to get adequate water flow & strength.)I do like the increased spray strength because I don't have to wait as long to fill my coffee carafe, and I can use the strength of the spray to do a good job rinsing clean dishes or silverware, much as a dishwasher's water flow batters the gunk off dishes.Other reviewers note that the aerator may fail in various ways after a year or three of use.  The manufacturer has included instructions for sustaining the life of the product, but this being the real world where everything eventually breaks down, it's not really going to last forever.  However, the manufacturer does provide a "lifetime guarantee", and it seems they will accept it back for exchange if it fails at any point with normal use, although they do require $3 to cover return shipping;  I think I'd just get a new one if this failed after a few years.  And that guarantee is still far better than plastic aerators, whose parts eventually crack because plastic can't stand up to the daily use, pressure, and tightening needed to make them functional.It still seems a bit odd to me that I'd rave so much about such a small, inexpensive item ... but this is one product that quite literally makes life easier for me on a daily basis.
summary: A bit pricey, but worth it

reviewText: Like another reviewer, I was struck by what my money actually bought me. This is a very poorly engineered system. First off, the way it's marketed led me to believe that it was a two-tray system. Well, it is...kinda. You can only grow one tray at a time and the second tray merely sits atop the first to hold in humidity. Interesting wording.Secondly, it's basically a bucket with pump mounted underneath; another bucket that sits on top of that grows your sprouts. The real handicap this system has is that to drain and refill the water bucket, one has to basically disassemble and reassemble the unit to accomplish this. The operation involves pulling the top bucket off while trying not to pull the bottom water-riser tube off with it, and then trying to realign the riser tubes while putting the bucket back on top of the base. Can be pretty tricky. It doesn't take much to imagine parts soon loosening up or breaking from the daily necessity of assembling/disassembling the unit.I've boxed mine up to return and will reinvest in a better system. In its favor I'll say that at least the pump motor is quiet. But overall it's a very poorly thought-out system and certainly not worth the money.

This pitcher holds 12 ounces when filled to the brim.  It is exactly the right size for a single, large cappuccino.It is made of heavier gauge steel than my other two pitchers (one that's too large and one that's too small).  The stainless steel appears to be excellent.  I doubt that rust will ever be a problem.The handle seems to be appropriately sized.  I didn't have any problem with it.  It is welded on with four spot welds.  The welds look like they'll be perfectly adequate for the occasional fall to the floor.  My smaller pitcher has only three spot welds and I have had no problems with it in the many years I have owned it.Altogether this is an excellent pitcher that is the perfect size for me.Update, one year (almost) later:The handle is still firmly attached to the pitcher, in spite of a couple of falls.  Still no rust either.I have bought a new cappuccino maker that makes a larger shot.  As a result I now need to froth more milk than when I bought this pitcher, so it's now just a bit too small.  I have switched back to my larger, 18-ounce (filled to the brim) pitcher.  I am keeping this smaller one to use with my old cappuccino maker in our RV.Apparently, this one is either just right or too small, depending upon your own style of coffee making.  If it's the right size, you won't go wrong with this pitcher.
summary: Just the right size for a single, large cappuccino

reviewText: This is a BEAUTIFUL headboard!  I couldn't have made a better choice and it arrived sooner than expected.  You CANNOT go wrong with this headboard!

I absolutely LOVED this machine for the few months that it worked. I mainly grinded nuts and seeds and also stuff like salt for popcorn topping. However, after about 6 months of moderate use it was struggling with some sesame seeds which it usually does okay and then as i tried to pulse it more, it just stopped and hasn't worked again.The company really needs to fix this motor issue coz when its working it fantastic.
summary: Loved it for a while but then it died

reviewText: I don't know if this is faulty or what but sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't.  I have to squeeze and turn and keep messing around until it will run.  Once I get it running it does a fine job.

Never arrived!it was not in the parcel with the other items.  The young man who answered my call said Amazon.com  was unable to reorder this item.  It does appear to be available on the site.  He was singularly unhelpful.
I use this to strain the fruit from my simple syrups. It works great at keeping the small strawberry or raspberry seeds out but lets the relatively thick syrup pass through.
Perfect box, panel for the bottom to keep the sides sturdy, decent price.  I only wish this had a label.  Still, I plan on purchasing more of these.  They fit perfectly into my snug cabinet space!
summary: Perfect-Just wish it had a label

reviewText: Received this and assembled in 5 minutes. Good quality and build. The anti slip pad that glues on the top surface easily falls off and is too small and flimsy. But without that, speaker bottom will scratch easily.
I like this strainer allot-  I make herbal infusions regularly and it provides adequate straining into bottles and is shaped to my funnel which works great.
The filters are exactly like the filters I used to pay much more for.  You cut them to fit and attach with strips that are included.  A bargain.

Overall, the Pinzon Pyrenees Down Support Standard pillow is a quality pillow. The 100% cotton cover is attractive, well-made and conveniently washable. A trip to Italy earlier this year made me realize that the coffee we're accustomed to drinking here in the States is absolutely terrible.  So after getting a full-time telecommuting job, I began researching different coffee makers on the market in hopes to make something as close as what I had overseas.  Taking in the rave reviews for many coffee makers out there (including the renowned Bialetti Moka Pot and Chemex pour-over), I ended up going with the AeroPress, and I'm glad I did.The AeroPress is unlike most coffee makers on the market, and probably more akin to the the Clover machine at Starbucks in how it extracts coffee.  There are plenty of videos on YouTube on how to use the AeroPress, so I won't explain how it works.While the AeroPress is marketed as an espresso maker, it doesn't exactly make an espresso that you may be used to getting in your corner coffee shop.  It makes a very strong and rich coffee, which you can add water or milk to to create different coffee drinks.  I've never gotten a nice creama on any of the drinks out of my AeroPress--you'll need a nice espresso maker for that.While I use the AeroPress every morning, I still keep my Keurig around for when guests are over and multiple people want to make coffee.  The one downside to the AeroPress is the time it takes to brew your coffee.  It's a good 2-3 minute manual task, where the Keurig takes almost no time or effort.  But I use my AeroPress nearly twice a day, and never once cared about how long it took to make a cup.For AeroPress newbies, here are a few tips:- If you have crappy coffee, don't bother: The AeroPress won't magically make your pre-packaged, grocery store coffee taste any better.  Buy good, fresh, whole bean coffee and grind it yourself.  Many places on the internet will roast coffee at time of order and ship it to your house.- Get a nice grinder: Burr grinders are the best and offer the best consistency, but you can get by with a blade grinder.- Stop when you hear the "hiss": In starting out with the AeroPress, you may be tempted to push the plunger all the way down to get every little bit of flavor out of your coffee.  Don't do this.  Plunging all the way down will simply give your coffee a bitter flavor.  To avoid this, stop plunging as soon as you hear the hissing sound.- Try to "invert" it: Follow the instructions in the AeroPress manual.  After doing so, try making coffee using the "inversion" method.  Google will tell you how to do this.  I prefer this method over the standard "AeroPress" way, but try it out and see what works for you.- Experiment, experiment, experiment!: The great thing about the AeroPress is that it gives you full control over your coffee.  Every nuance of the coffee making process, from how much coffee and water you use to the precise temperature and steep time you use, is up to you!
summary: Great Coffee Maker--Just Make Sure to use Quality Coffee!

reviewText: Let me tell you about my sister.  She has everything.  She loves to cook and always in the kitchen.  She had her chicken motiff, a cow motiff, a grape motiff, and now she loves pigs.  Every Christmas I buy her things for her kitchen.  Imagine my delight when I saw this pig shaped cutting board.  I opened it for inspection before re-wrapping in Christmas paper.  Although pig shaped, it is big enough in the main area for actual use.  I love the hole in the tail for hanging if she chooses.  It was thick and heavy, and made of quality wood.  I've no doubt it will be used for chopping and cutting, and still hung to enhance her pig decorations.  I can't wait to see her face and know that she'll actually use it.  I won't tell her the price was great quality for less money.lajammer

reviewText: ----------Update #2----------After about about 6 months, the replacement mill started working inconsistently like the first one I had (it was like clockwork because that is when my first one did the same thing).  Eventually,  it bit the dust altogether.  Very disappointed in this mill.  I still have to give kudos for the customer service, but I won't be buying another Ozeri.----------Update #1----------After this review, someone from the company commented and offered to send me a new pepper mill.  I responded to the email address, and sent my name and order ID (per the company's request).  Within a week, I received a new pepper mill in the mail.  They also sent a return label so that I can send my old pepper mill back, free of charge - if someone from the company is reading this, it will be in the mail tomorrow :-)So far, the pepper mill seems to be working well.  But, my old one did for a while too.  So, I'll have to wait and see how this one does.But, in the meantime, I have to give Ozeri MAJOR KUDOS for their wonderful customer service.  Good customer service is hard to come by nowadays. And, I think many of us have a tendency to complain when there is bad customer service. For good measure, I wanted to take the time to compliment good customer service.THANK YOU, OZERI!!!----------Original Review----------I used to own theMIU France Battery Powered Electric Peppermill/Grinder, Black.  But, it broke after one too many times dropped.  I loved that pepper mill. The only problem with it was that it was too unsteady and would fall over (hence, me dropping it).When it came time to purchase another pepper mill, I bought this one from Ozeri.Pros:- Sturdy base - Hasn't dropped, fallen over once- Has a lid - Although, it is hard to put on sometimes- Adjustable grind - although, most pepper mills have this- Nice flow of pepper...when it actually works (*See Con #2*)Cons:- Putting it back together after replacing the batteries is a bit of a pain- It is too inconsistent.  Sometimes it works great, others it is just stops (and, it's not because of the batteries).  I end up having to flip it over a few times and shake it to get it to work again.I have had this for about 6 months.  Because of the inconsistency of the pepper mill, I am going to toss it and purchase another MIU (and, be more careful with it).
summary: Good when it works, but inconsistent

reviewText: Our living room is awkward and really only has room for a couch, no big end tables but we needed something to put drinks on etc. so we grabbed this table.  It was packed VERY well, easy to assemble and looks great.  Not to mention you can't beat the price.  Would definitely recommend!

I had this in my wish list for quite a while before ordering. I read lots of negative reviews but decided to get anyway. I am glad I did!First I want to say that you really have to watch it when assembling. The instructions aren't that great, mostly photos, but it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure assembly out.  I put one of the racks on upside down and after puttng it together, had to take it apart and re-do. I was excited to get it so wasn't paying attention. It only takes a few minutes to do so that was no problem. You do NOT need any tools to put together or take apart. <A MALLET - REALLY??> A shove with the butt of your hand will get the shelves out from the plastic shelf grippers. I bought 2 of these as I have a very large cabinet and it took me 20 minutes to put both together, including taking the first apart and back together again.If you don't get those shelf grippers on correctly, the shelf will wobble. I was worried I wasn't doing it right because they don't close all the way - but they are just fine with the shelves on.Be sure to read the item description for size - lot of complaints that this is small. It does say CABINET Organzer so not sure how big you'd want it - most cabinets are around the size of this shelf. I was able to put over 70 cans on one rack - about 20-25 on each shelf - tomato paste, picante/hot sauce, green beans, peas, carrots, condensed milk, etc. The bottom rack alone has 6 large cans that weigh 1 pound 12 ounces each < 16 pounds approx. there> and 6 regular size cans <14.75 ounces - 1.6 pounds each> for a total of about 23 pounds on the bottom shelf. I put boxed food on the other shelf, although I might switch for more canned food items.Not sure what everyone is talking about regarding rusting? My shelves are in a cabinet next to my stove and have been there for over 2  months and I haven't had to clean them and they look just as brand new as the day I bought them. I would suggest using a dry rag to "dust off" if you feel the need? Since my shelves are holding canned food - there is no wetness. They are in my kitchen and we cook all the time and the sink is in the same room, and my laundry is in the very next room - but none of that has affected my shelves. And I live in Texas where the humidity is ridiculously high!I like that I am able to see all the items on my shelf without having to dig around the cabinet. We did have to remove a shelf in order for it to fit as it was higher then I expected, but that is no big deal - I can put the shelf back in if I decide to move the rack. I also like that you can adjust the height of the racks to whatever you want - they don't have to be as the photo shows. AND I like that the shelves store easily as they come apart easy. Remember to keep the little plastic feet that they shipped with so the racks aren't touching and won't scracth the metal in storage.The construction of these organizers is well made, strong and I can see them ladting for many years. I am very happy with my purchase and would definitely recommend this product!I posted a photo of my rack, it's the last photo showng canned foods.
summary: AWESOME Racking! VERY Easy Assembly - Strong - Nice Looking!

reviewText: There are a many collections of stainless cookware sold these days as people flee from Teflon based non-sticks. If you go to Wal*Mart, they will be happy to sell you an extremely cheaply made stainless set for less than  a third of this set. Don't  do it. The ultra cheap ones have shoddy rivets which will leak and give way over time, and do not have the thick disk of heat conducting aluminum which will prevent hot spots from scorching your food. Nor do they have the beautiful heat delaying silicon rubber handles of this set, or the silicon rubber gaskets around the lids. Cookware should last a lifetime, and should be bought with an eye towards long term value.Let me walk you through a simple recipe, and how well the qualities of these pots made my life easier. Shepherd's Pie calls for mashed potatoes, sauteing meat and vegetables, finishing with time in the oven. I choose the 3Qt sauce pan for the potatoes, and the 3Qt sauteing pan for everything else. The sauce pan is tall and of ample capacity to boil 3 large quartered potatoes, its big aluminum disk delivered the heat to the water efficiently and without big bumps from hot spots. And the gasketed lid stayed on quietly. After cooking, I drained the pot, and just used a big wooden spoon to mash the potatoes inside the pot. The pot is tall for its size, and this seems to make it easier to mash without mess. The sauteing pan was big enough to brown a full pound of lamb without having to resort to batches, and then to accept a large chopped onion, carrots and mushrooms without overflowing. Everything cooked uniformly, even while doing a reduction. Then beef stock for a quick deglaze and a simmer under the pan's beautiful lid. There was plenty of room to put the mashed potatoes on top. And finally, the whole pan could be put in the oven to melt and brown a topping of cheese.  Afterwards, everything cleaned up easily as there were no hotspot traps for scorched food.I had not known what I was missing in terms of having to work around my old pans.Not that these pans are for everyone. They are not non-stick. If you don't deglaze frequently in your cuisine, or aren't sure what deglazing is, then maybe you would prefer something non-stick like anodized aluminum, or enameled iron, or even an old fashioned iron skillet. I have an anodized omelet pan and there is no way I would use any of the pans in this collection to cook an omelet. Life is just too short.The handles are nice, but don't expect them to eliminate the need for oven mitts. Yes, you can handle the stock pots and saute pans on the stove top with comfort, usually, but you can't expect a stock pot filled with bubbling water not to have hot handles, much less any pot coming out of an oven. They are lovely though, and comfortable grasping the silicon grips when cool to warm.The lids are great because of their gaskets, keeping a nice quiet connection with the pot, but I don't know that there is much benefit to their being see through, at least when dealing with anything with water in it. The lids very rapidly form a translucent layer of micro drops making it pretty much impossible to peer into the covered pot.  Again, they are certainly lovely though.Everything cleans nicely in the dishwasher, excepting the stock pot which is too large for my dishwasher.I'm very happy with this set, and think it well worth any additional cost above el-cheapo sets you might find at discount or warehouse stores--the display model for the stainless steel cookware set my local BJ's sells was already falling apart. If I were interested in getting a set for an inexperienced cook, I might look at jumping toKitchenAid's anodized cookwarewhich look sweet indeed, or at least acquiring a few additional anodized pieces. Still if you are serious about cooking, this is a good starting point.
Was so pleased with it I bought my daughter one.  I have learned we can always trust Amazon.com.  It is dependable and secure.

Fine mesh strainers always clogged the sink, but the larger holes and thicker, more durable construction of the RSVP stainless steel strainers are easy to clean and strain quickly.  You can hand wash the strainer or place it in the dishwasher for effective cleaning, something that cannot be accomplished with a fine mesh strainer that requires rigorous scrubbing.  Fine mesh strainers which slow the water flow through the kitchen pipes may hasten the accumulation of mold/mildew, oils, and debris.  However, the RSVP strainer allows a faster flow of water while straining out larger particles, keeping your pipes cleaner.  I purchased many of these and highly recommend this great product!

After four years of use and following washing/drying instructions (low heat drying) the rubberized backing is coming off.Also, this product traps heat when I sleep.  Unfortunately I think the latter problem may be true of ALL of the "waterproof, dust mite protection" mattress covers, since they all have terry cloth exteriors lined with a thin layer of a rubberized compound.

I used to be a drip coffee kind of guy but ever since going to Europe, I've bailed on that in favor of pressure brewed or in this case, the press. Solidly built all metal construction, double insulated keeps coffee hot longer. The finish outside is mirror-like stainless. Makes a nice robust, stout cup of coffee without a hint of bitterness. I get a donut store bean that I've become quite fond of and use a burr grinder. Excellent taste. Bought an all metal electric water kettle that boils much faster than on the stove to use with this as well. I leave both sit out on my counter all the time. The only down side is I sometimes forget to empty the grounds when I'm done for the morning and have to deal with the clean up in the morning before I can make another pot.  Very minor dilemma....still 5 stars, LOVE this thing!!

I've used the item for over a month, predominantly for hot coffee, occasionally for tea.  Here's the skinny:1. It holds 11 oz.(measured with a measuring cup) filled to the brim.  You can fill right to the brim because of the sealing lid.2. It keeps my coffee at the desired temperature several times longer than my formerly favorite ceramic mug.3. The outside of the cup does not stain (nor the inside).4. You can microwave stuff in it.5. It absolutely does not leak with the lid on.6. It has a very pleasant heft to it.7. Even if you like your coffee very hot, the outside of the cup never reaches more than a very pleasant warmth.8. I cannot detect any plastic odor from the silicone lid.9. And yes, people get a kick out of it!

reviewText: This is such a great product for any wine lover. I love that it comes with two plugs, so I can have one white and one red open and not be worried about wasting a good bottle. I am rather disappointed in this product.  I had a Hamilton Beach slow cooker (about this size) that I broke the lid on when I moved to my new house and never could find a new lid for it.  When I saw this product through the Vine program, I was so excited as I thought they they should be equivalent.  That was a wrong assumption.  This product is not near as heavy as my Hamilton Beach.  In fact, this one has a very thin, tinny sounding outer housing.  I find that the lid does not fit real tight on it.  While that is OK (probably) to let out steam, this Black and Decker unit just does not have the substantial feeling of my old cooker or seems to work as well.  There are a lot of "don'ts" in the instructions about what you can or how you should cook.  So much so that I feel that it takes away from some of the joy of cooking with a slow cooker.  While I will use this item as I love to make soup and stews in a slow cooker, I think I will continue to look for a lid to replace on my Hamilton Beach.
summary: Just not the substantial produce that my older slow cooker was

I bought this travel cup because I love unique thing- this really is one of the first travel cups to come out that looked like a paper cup.  When I got this cup about a year and a half ago, I got a lot of comments and compliments from other people on how interesting this cup is.  Beyond the appearance of this cup is of course that it is environmentally friendly, not that I am a hippie, but some people really like to know that they are having a positive impact on their consumption of resources.This cup doesn't leak from the silicone lid, that seals over the porcelain.  The only place you may find leaking is out of the hole you drink from.  Also, the inside of this cup is smooth and sealed, unlike the porous exterior that resembles paper.  This is great because it means clean-up is easy!The cup is dual-walled, so hot things stay hotter longer and cold things stay colder longer.I love all the features of this cup and would buy again in a heart beat- not that I need to because this cup has been going strong for over a year and a half!

update feb. 2009:this is the best espresso maker on the market,, we have now used it for a couple of years making an avg of 20 coffees espressos or cappicinos a day.  after all this use we have had no problems with the system.  it froths our milk it makes great coffee and as i said a couple of years a go my problem is filling the water container all the time.  i no longer use the water filters as i now have a commercial r.o. filtration system in my home.  since the jura is in a detached rec room i have friends who stop by nearly every day to chat and have a coffee, i have a reputation for having the best coffee in town.----------------------------------ive now owned my z5 for about 2 months, and it is fun, weve already gone through a cleary water filter. our favorite thing about the machine is the frother we normally drink capucinos and oh my is this easy, and its fully programmable. i bought 2 extra milk carafes for chocolate milk and eggnog and i have solved the souring problem by adding about 25 percent ice cubes to each thermos, as the ice melts it waters down the milks which make for a better froth, dont try to use too thick a milk like eggnog it may not pull it through the siphon, water it down or add skim for a really nice froth.  i also own a manual breville which i really love for those real expensive gourmet coffees that make a single perfect shot of espresso, but i still use the frother on the jura becuase its perfect everytime.  So far the jura makes a better espresso for me then i can make manually so i have started grinding my expensive coffees with a burr grinder and having the jura make it for me. i love technology that allows me to enjoy coffee that only an expert could make in the past.  I should have given it 5 stars but we use it so much we run it out of water and although it has the largest tank in its class its still too small, if they make a wider model that has a tank on both sides, i would buy it.
Use this on a routine basis. High quality and works great!

The biggest problem in cleaning spots and stains out of furniture and area rugs is lugging around a heavy piece of equipment. This Hoover is small enough to carry with ease and fills simply from the top. It even has a  built in mechanism so it can't overflow. I liked its performance overall  and found it as good, if not better then other household machines. Of  course it seems to work best with the cleaner it came with but since it's  an economical product that isn't a problem either. The best feature it has  is two separate tanks which means you won't end up cleaning your sofa with  dirty water. Overall this product is a good investment and pasys for itself  in one use.

I've had this knife for years, use it for everything and couldn't be happier.  I thought it would dull easily or wear down, after all it's only $10, but I was wrong.  Simply fantastic for cutting bread, but also useful for vegetables and other tasks.  The only thing it doesn't cut well is meat.

This device makes a good cup of coffee.  As advertised, it minimizes the bitter tones and lets the true coffee flavor shine through.  It doesn't quite taste like any other brewing method I've tried.  I think it can be best described as lacking a bitter tone as well as a reduced acidity flavor.  It is fast and convenient. Great for when I only have a few minutes to make a coffee or when I don't want to wake up the kids with the espresso machine.  Speaking of the espresso, don't assume this thing will make you a double shot of great espresso.  It will with single serving produce about the equivalent volume as a double shot of espresso, it can not compete with the flavor and delicate nuances of great espresso.  My Gaggia Classic produces some great espresso when I do my part, and the AeroPress can't compete with that.  But I think that is an apples to oranges comparison.  Bottom line: good to great cup of coffee, but espresso it is not.

I ordered this table to match existing furniture I have with an espresso finish. This table is not espresso, it is very, very black. Otherwise, it is a nice table. It arrived with no damage and was easy to assemble. It is sturdy. Unfortunately, it is just the wrong color.I'd send it back, but my husband assembled it before I even saw it come out of the box. If you're looking specifically for an espresso finish, look elsewhere.

I bought this as a gift for my son-in-law and he swears that, in conjunction with the little hand grinder, it makes the best espresso he's ever had.  I haven't personally tasted this sublime nectar, but I will take his word.  This man knows his coffee.

Pyrex has two product lines, Storageware (of which this set is a part) and Serveware, that really should be combined.  As others have pointed out, this set could be improved by having some larger bowls.  The Serveware line features larger bowls, made of textured glass, that look nicer on the table than these plain glass bowls.  But the Serveware bowls don't come with lids; you need to use disposable plastic wrap for refrigerator storage.The bowls in this set have mostly straight sides.  While this is more efficient for storing things in your refrigerator, it's less so for stacking the set in your cupboards when not in use.  A bit more taper in the sides would let the same-size bowls stack better.  The Serveware bowls have quite a lot of taper in the sides, so they stack together well in the cupboard but don't use space in the refrigerator efficiently.Here's what Pyrex needs to produce: a set of bowls, mostly larger than in this set, with the attractive texture of the Serveware line.  The sides should have a moderate amount of taper so they'll stack together in your cupboards.  They should have lids that fit the bowls.WATCH OUT for mismatched lids.  My set came with the correct assortment of bowls, but 5 small lids for the 4 small bowls and only 1 medium lid for the 2 medium bowls.  Of course I didn't check this until I'd already run the full set through the dishwasher and torn the box apart for curbside recycling.  I would have rated the set 4 stars without this warehouse goof.
summary: A few changes could improve this line

reviewText: I do alot of cooking and need heavy duty pans.. These are worth the money.This pan is well-made, heavy and durable.. A must in any kitchen.

Works well but it is a bit quirky the way you have to assemble it to use.  It seems a bit flimsy, but everything has held up well with no problems. Well, after reading all the positive reviews, we purchased the CC 120. For many years, I've been sharpening our kitchen knives by hand ... using both oil stones and water stones ... with great results. It was tedious and took hours for all the knives, so I tried the Chef's Choice. What a dissapointment.After carefully reading the instructions, I used the sharpener on a few of the knives. The manual suggests the knife would be sharp enough to cut paper. Nope. Hand sharpening produces a much better edge (cuts paper) which is then easy to keep true with a steel.This one will be returned.Followup:I subscribe to Cook's Illustrated and they indicated that it takes roughly 14 passes (7 on each side) to achieve a good edge. I tried it followed by 6 passes through the polisher (3 on each side). The knife I tried this approach on is definately very sharp and cuts paper.That being said an IMO, too much metal is removed in the process, so I'll stick with hand-sharpening.However, I will keep this CC 120 since I paid only $90 for the chrome model.

reviewText: Makes amazingly smooth purees. So smooth in fact, that the first time I ate a soup puree I had to get used to the texture. Ha!The few things I've tried I've been very pleased with: grinding nuts, chopping veggies, pureeing soups, smoothing mashed potatoes, making smoothies and chopping ice. the only thing I have to watch is when "chopping veggies" - the chopping isn't 100% even and you have to be careful to pulse quickly but not too much or you'll end up with a puree in no time.I love the multi-leveled blades. I have yet to have anything get stuck like a regular blender. Clean-up is super easy - everything (but the power source) is machine washable.I love the three container sizes and the pour spout on the large cover.Be careful - the blades are SUPER sharp! reviewText: Evaporative coolers, also known as "swamp coolers" DO NOT WORK if there is any humidity in the air.  Unless you live in a high desert, these devices can actually add to your hot sweaty misery by increasing the humidity in your house and possibly even warming it because of heat generated by the fan and pumps.  Higher humidity can even cause mold and mildew problems. Remember if the air is saturated with humidity the water in this device can't evaporate and it can't cool the air.High desert = GreatAnywhere else = Don't bother
